resources.string: Description \n The Vigenère cipher is a method of encrypting alphabetic text by using a simple form of polyalphabetic substitution. Instead of using a single fixed substitution for each letter, like in the Caesar cipher, the Vigenère cipher uses a key to determine different substitutions for each letter. The key is repeated to match the length of the message, and each letter in the message is shifted according to its corresponding letter in the key.

Description \n The XOR (exclusive OR) cipher is a simple and bitwise encryption technique. It operates by applying the XOR operation between each character of the plaintext and a corresponding character in a secret key. The ciphertext is produced by this bitwise operation.

Description \nA transposition cipher involves rearranging the order of characters in the plaintext to create the ciphertext. Unlike substitution ciphers, transposition ciphers do not replace the characters; instead, they change the position of the characters inside the string.

Description \n A substitution cipher is a method of encryption where each letter in the plaintext is replaced with another letter or symbol according to a predetermined system. The most straightforward example is the Caesar cipher, which shifts each letter by a fixed amount.
Usage \n Enter your desired key and message as letters. All letters will be converted to uppercase, and no whitespace is allowed.

Usage \n Enter a message and key of your choice. Both will be converted to binary and XORed bit by bit. Toggle the binary switch to view the binary representation, as the ciphertext may not consist of readable symbols.

Usage \n Enter a message of your choice. Provide the key as a permutation of positions, separated by whitespace. For example, \"(1 2 3)(10 23)\" will swap places 10 and 23, and shift the first symbol to the second position, the second to the third, and the third to the first position. 0 is not allowed as an index.

Usage \n Enter a message of your choice. Provide the key as permutation of symbols without seperating them, as whitespaces are considered symbols. For example, \"(abc)(9@)\" will replace a\'s with b\'s, b\'s with c\'s, and c\'s with a\'s. 9 and @ will be swapped.

Purpose of this app \n\ This app provides a simple way to play around with simple ciphers, encrypting and decrypting messages to gain intuition for this process. More ciphers and more detailed insight into the encryption/decryption process will be added in the future.
